chapter.title: Image Handling

chapter.para: Depending on the output format you generate with &dapsacr; (PDF or HTML for example), the source images you provide and reference in your XML sources can automatically be transformed into different output formats (from SVG to PNG for example). This section describes the basic things you need to know for using images (supported formats, where to store the images in your documentation directory, and how to reference them). For the more advanced image handling features (like listing images referenced in your XML files or the one used for output formats, list any missing images or checking for unique image names), refer to .

sect1.title: Location of the Images
sect1.para: &dapsacr; requires a certain directory structure for your XML sources and for your images that you want to reference there. For details, refer to . Depending on the file type of your source images, add them to the respective subdirectories in YOUR_DOC_DIR/images/src.

important.title: Unique Image Names
important.para: The base names of your images need to be unique throughout the image subdirectories. For example, using images/svg/AAA.svn and images/svg/AAA.png will not work. taroth 2012-03-19: check with fs what happens in this case The name in front of the file extension needs to be different, for example: images/svg/AAA.svn and images/svg/BBB.png.

sect1.title: Referencing Images
sect1.para: Provided your images are located in the required default directory, &dapsacr; automatically finds the path to your images. Therefore referencing images in your XML sources is very straightforward: you do not need to include any path in the fileref attribute—the file name is enough.

Furthermore DocBook allows you to insert more than one image to distinguish between different target formats. For example, you can add two images pointing to the same file, but with different widths. Use the role attribute and add the name of the target format (fo, html, etc.)
